title: Window Shade, "Russia", 1938–39
provenance: Gift of Doris Duke Charitable Foundation; window shade was one of six commissioned by Doris Duke for theatre in Hollywood Wing at Duke Farms. Shades were de-installed from the Duke Farms Theatre and delivered directly to Cooper-Hewitt,
dimensions:
L x W x D: 518.2 x 162.6 cm (17 ft. x 5 ft. 4 in.)
L x W: 408.9 x 166.4 cm (13 ft. 5 in. x 5 ft. 5 1/2 in.)
creditline: Gift of Doris Duke Charitable Foundation
description: Large central male figure surrounded by architecture with onion-like cupolas, peacock, stringed instrument. Horse-drawn cart at bottom, fish under man's foot, bowl of caviar.
justification:
These six window shades were created for the theatre in the Hollywood Wing of Duke Farms in Hillsborough, NJ.&nbsp; The original house dates to 1893 and was the home of James Buchanan Duke who made his wealth in tobacco and hydroelectric power.&nbsp; He gained a competitive edge by being the first person to successfully use machines to roll cigarettes.&nbsp; The Hollywood Wing was added by daughter Doris Duke in 1938-39.&nbsp; The theatre was designed by Thomas W. Lamb, (1871-1942) one of the foremost theatre and cinema architects during the late19th - early 20th century.&nbsp; He designed many of the most well-known theatres in New York City and across the country including the Ziegfield Theatre, 1927, Madison Square Garden, 1925, and the Academy of Music (later the Palladium Theatre) in 1927.&nbsp; The window shades are hand painted on canvas. &nbsp;
The theme of the six shades is music and dance which are all rendered in an art deco/cubist style.&nbsp; Each shade contains a central figure which portrays a different country or region including Africa, China, Switzerland, Hawaii, Mexico and Russia.&nbsp; Each of the figures is surrounded by elements of folk tradition mixed with historic elements specific to that country or region.&nbsp; This portrayal of the different regions is inspired by the classic four continents theme which included Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas.
